Title: How price perception and satisfaction influence online repurchase intention
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Heriyati, P., Management Department, BINUS Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia; Budharani, A., Management Department, BINUS Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University (BINUS), Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: This research investigates how price perception, performance and satisfaction of Indonesian consumers impact online shopping experience and online repurchase intention at the same shops. The study specifically examines the important interrelationship between three variables that affect customer's intention to repurchase. The results facilitate the understanding of factors that influence repurchase intention of online shopping in Jakarta. One hundred valid responses from a set questionnaires were analysed. Regression analysis was employed to test the hypotheses. The results showed the customer's price perception and after-delivery satisfaction influenced their overall satisfaction and their intention to return to the same online shop (e-Tailer). In addition, overall satisfaction influenced repurchase intention at e-Tailer. Customer at-checkout satisfaction was not found to influence the overall satisfaction and their intention to return to shop at the same e-Tailer. The findings suggested that customers after checking-out from an e-Tailer required further favourable experiences to support their judgment and decision to return to the same online shop. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: After-delivery satisfaction; At-checkout satisfaction; Intention to return online; Overall satisfaction; Price perception
Funding Text 1: This research was supported by Bina Nusantara University. Authors would like to thank their colleagues from the Faculty of Business and the Academic Development Unit who provided insight and expertise that greatly assisted the research.
